text.p: Indian state-controlled crude oil refiner Cochin Refineries on Saturday resumed operations after a five-day shutdown, a company spokesman said.
"The refinery has started working again. It is running normally," the spokesman told Reuters From the southern city of Cochin.
The refinery resumed operations at 8 a.m. (0230 GMT) on Saturday, the spokesman said.

Production at the 150,000 barrels-per-day refinery, located on the southwest coast of India, halted on Monday when water supply dwindled to 8,450 kilolitres per day compared to the refinery's daily demand of 22,750. The spokesman said the refiner had stocked 60,000 kilolitres of water, equivalent to the required three days' supply for operations to resume.
"The water authority has agreed to give us normal water supply," he said.
He said the firm had not yet calculated its losses due to the closure. Company officials earlier said the state government was losing nearly 30 million rupees ($838,000) a day due to the shutdown.
